__data__.text: Barcelona is the capital and largest city of the autonomous community of Catalonia in Spain.
Barcelona is located in the Spanish Levant, on the Mediterranean coast.
The geographical coordinates of Barcelona are between 41°16' and 41°30' north latitude and between 1°54' and 2°18' east longitude.
The area of Barcelona is 102.16 km².
Barcelona is situated on a plain that is about 11 km long and 6 km wide.
The Collserola mountain range bounds Barcelona on one side, with the summit of Tibidabo (516.2 m) as its highest point.
The Llobregat river delta and the Besós river delta bound Barcelona on another side.
Montjuïc (184.8 m) is a mountain in Barcelona that is above the coastline and separates the city from the Llobregat delta.
Several hills are located in the plain of Barcelona, including La Peira (133 m), La Rovira (261 m), El Carmel (267 m), Creueta del Coll (249 m), El Putget (181 m), and Monterols (121 m).
The plain of Barcelona has a uniform slope from the sea to the Collserola mountain range, with an ascent of about 260 m.
The terrain of Barcelona is formed by a substrate of slate and granitic formations, as well as clays and limestones.
The coast of Barcelona was formerly occupied by tidal marshes and salt-water lagoons.
The coastline of Barcelona has been able to advance about 5 km since the sixth century BC.
The area of the plain was formerly crossed by numerous torrents and streams.
The climate of Barcelona is Mediterranean, with mild winters.
The temperature in Barcelona usually ranges between 9.5 °C and 24.3 °C.
Rainfall in Barcelona is low, about 600 mm per year.
Most of the precipitation in Barcelona occurs in spring and autumn
Barcelona is divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods.
The district of Ciutat Vella has an area of 4.49 km² and a population of 100 685 inhabitants.
Ciutat Vella corresponds to the old core of the city, including the Roman and medieval periods, plus the Barceloneta neighborhood.
The district of Ciutat Vella received much immigration from the rest of Spain during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
The population of Ciutat Vella has the oldest and lowest socioeconomic level in the city.
A slow process of gentrification has begun in Ciutat Vella in the new millennium.
Ciutat Vella has numerous monuments and architectural works of interest.
The district of Ciutat Vella houses the most important institutions of the city, such as the City Hall or the Generalitat de Catalunya.
The district of Eixample has an area of 7.46 km² and a population of 263,565 inhabitants.
Eixample arose from the expansion of the old city after the demolition of the walls.
Eixample was mainly a residential area where wealthy families stayed after leaving the old part of the city.
The social level in Eixample corresponds mainly to the middle class.
Eixample is an important focus of tourist attraction, especially due to the presence of modernist architectural works.
The district of Sants-Montjuïc has an area of 21.35 km² and a population of 180,824 inhabitants.
Sants-Montjuïc includes the old town of Sants, annexed to Barcelona in 1897.
The rate of population of foreign origin in Sants-Montjuïc exceeds the average.
Sants-Montjuïc has a high percentage of green area, thanks mainly to the presence of the Montjuic mountain.
The district of Les Corts has an area of 6.08 km² and a population of 81,200 inhabitants.
Les Corts comes from the old town of Les Corts de
The district of Horta-Guinardó has an area of 11.96 km² and a population of 166,950 inhabitants.
The old center of Horta-Guinardó is characterized by narrow streets and tightly packed houses.
The population of Horta-Guinardó has a high percentage of elderly people.
The level of education in Horta-Guinardó is above average.
Most of the population in Horta-Guinardó are of lower-middle social class.
Horta-Guinardó was an agricultural area in the early nineteenth century.
The district of Horta-Guinardó began to forge an urban and industrial fabric in the early nineteenth century.
The district of Horta-Guinardó has one of the highest population densities in the city.
The district of Nou Barris has an area of 8.04 km² and a population of 164,516 inhabitants.
Nou Barris is the most recently created district.
Nou Barris was created on land segregated from Sant Andreu de Palomar.
Nou Barris is a peripheral area.
The population of Nou Barris is predominantly immigrant.
Nou Barris suffered from strong real estate speculation.
Nou Barris even suffered from shantyism and self-construction.
Nou Barris has suffered from a significant lack of assistance, infrastructure and basic services.
The majority of the population in Nou Barris is working class.
Nou Barris has low purchasing power.
The district of Sant Andreu has an area of 6.56 km² and a population of 145,983 inhabitants.
Sant Andreu corresponds to the former municipality of Sant Andreu de Palomar, annexed in 1897.
Sant Andreu was an agricultural and milling area until the mid-nineteenth century.
Numerous industries began to settle in Sant Andreu in the mid-nineteenth century.
Sant
The Raval quarter was added in the 15th century, creating a division that lasted until the 18th century.
In 1769, a reform was made, and five quarters were created. Each quarter was subdivided into eight neighborhoods.
I-Palacio quarter included the port and the new neighborhood of Barceloneta.
II-San Pedro quarter was an eminently industrial area.
III-Audiencia quarter corresponded to the center of the city.
IV-Casa de la Ciudad quarter was a mostly residential area.
V-Raval quarter included the land west of La Rambla.
Numerous divisions were made in the 19th century for political reasons.
The districts also marked the electoral districts.
The most notable divisions were those of 1837 and 1878.
In 1837, the city was divided into four districts: Lonja, San Pedro, Universidad and San Pablo.
In 1878, after the demolition of the walls, 10 districts were established.
The 10 districts established in 1878 were: I-La Barceloneta, II-Borne, III-Lonja, IV-Atarazanas, V-Hospital, VI-Audiencia, VII-Instituto, VIII-Universidad, IX-Hostafranchs and X-Concepción.
Several neighboring municipalities were added to the city between the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
A new administrative reorganization was carried out with 10 districts.

The 10 districts established between the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries were: I-Barceloneta and Pueblo Nuevo, II-San Pedro, III-Lonja and Audiencia, IV-Concepción, V-Atarazanas and Hospital, VI-Universidad, VII-Sans, Las Corts and Hostafranchs, VIII-Gracia and San Gervasio, IX-Horta and Sant Andreu de Palomar, X-Sant Martí de Provençals.
In
Seventy-three neighborhoods were established in Barcelona, with the decision causing controversy due to the fragmentation of some historical neighborhoods.
The neighborhood of El Clot was segregated into El Camp de l'Arpa.
The neighborhood of Sants was segregated into the neighborhood of Badal.
The neighborhood Esquerra de l'Eixample was divided between La Nova and L'Antiga Esquerra de l'Eixample.
The neighborhood of Poblenou was fragmented into five neighborhoods.
Some neighborhood units were not satisfied with their aspirations to become neighborhoods, including Can Caralleu, Penitents, Torre Melina, and El Polvorí.
Barcelona was founded by Roman colonizers in the first century BC with the name of Barcino.
The original Barcino was a small walled city with an urban form of castrum, seated on the Mons Taber.
The maximum splendor of the Roman period in Barcino took place during the second century.
The population of Barcino during the second century must have ranged between 3500 and 5000 inhabitants.
The main reason for the choice of a small promontory near the coast to build Barcino was its natural harbor.
The center of Barcino was the forum, the central square dedicated to public life and business.
The forum was located at the confluence of the cardus maximus and the decumanus maximus.
The cardus maximus was located on Llibreteria and Call streets.
The decumanus maximus was located on Bisbe, Ciutat and Regomir streets.
The city followed an orthogonal layout, with square or rectangular blocks, following a grid layout.
The grid layout was based on two main axes: a horizontal axial order (northwest-southwest) and a vertical one (southeast-northeast).
The layout of the city was collected by Ildefonso Cerdá in his Plan de Eixample of 1859.
The Romans were great experts in architecture and civil engineering.
The period in discussion is marked by the reuse of the Roman city with its urban structure remaining largely unchanged.
This period saw Barcelona being considered as a military stronghold, which led to its hegemony over other surrounding cities and its establishment as the capital of its territory.
The colonization of the surrounding countryside began during this time, within a feudal structure.
A certain suburbanization also began, with the appearance of the first suburbs.
During the Middle Ages, Barcelona was constituted as a county and later became part of the Crown of Aragon.
Barcelona became the political and economic center of the Principality of Catalonia, becoming an important maritime and commercial axis of the Mediterranean Sea.
The city grew from the primitive urban core, which is now the Gothic Quarter.
In the 14th century, the Raval district emerged.
At that time, Barcelona had about 25,000 inhabitants.
Medieval Barcelona arose from the reconstruction of the city after its near destruction by Almanzor in 985.
The city underwent numerous changes as a center of political and religious power.
The city also transformed as a center of trade and craft production.
The city became the nexus of a new and complex network of social and institutional relations.
The city acquired an autonomy of its own, a singularity within the surrounding territory.
The city became the center of a hinterland that would mark the organization of the modern city.
The progressive increase in the size of the city led to the creation of a specific system of government for the administration of the city, the Council of One Hundred in 1265.
The Council of One Hundred operated in a field of action that went from Montcada to Molins de Rei, and from Castelldefels to Montgat.
The Council of One Hundred was responsible for the supply of food and water, the maintenance of roads, the census of the population and territorial demarcation.
The Council of One Hundred established the first urban building patterns, known as Consuetuds de Santacilia and promulgated by James
The Raval neighborhood was initially a suburb with orchards and some religious buildings.
The monastery of Sant Pau del Camp was built in 914.
The church of Sant Antoni Abat was built in 1157.
The convent of the Carmelites Calçats was built in 1292.
The priory of Nazareth was built in 1342.
The monastery of Montalegre was built in 1362.
In 1260, a new wall was built from Sant Pere de les Puelles to the Drassanes, facing the sea.
The new section of the wall was 5100 m long and covered an area of 1.5 km².
The enclosure had eighty towers and eight new gates.
The network of fortifications in the urban periphery was built for the defense of the city.
The castle of the Port was built in Montjuïc.
The castles of Martorell and Castellví de Rosanes were built at the entrance of the Llobregat river.
The castles of Eramprunyà and Castelldefels were built in the delta of the Llobregat river.
The castle of Montcada was built at the entrance of the Besòs river.
The medieval urban fabric was marked by different areas of influence.
The network of streets was irregular.
The squares were mere widenings of the streets or plots of land derived from the demolition of a house.
The houses were usually of the "artisan type".
The larger buildings were either churches or palaces, along with some institutional buildings.
In 1209, the opening of Montcada street took place.
Montcada street was a wide, straight street.
The Plaça Nova was opened next to the Episcopal Palace in 1355.
The continuous urban growth led to a new extension of the walled enclosure.
The Raval wall was constructed in the
The urbanization of a place was completed in 1444. During the Middle Ages, it was the widest space in the city and was used for strolling, leisure, and occasional markets.
The place is one of the most emblematic of the city today.

During the Middle Ages, an extensive network of roads emerged in the plain of Barcelona. These roads connected the city with suburbs, villages, farmhouses, mills, quarries, bleaching meadows, churches, chapels, fountains, etc.
In the Early Modern Age, Barcelona and Catalonia became part of the Hispanic Monarchy.
The Early Modern Age was a time of alternation between periods of prosperity and economic crisis.
Plague epidemics occurred in the sixteenth century.
Social and military conflicts such as the Reapers' War and the War of Succession occurred between the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.
The economy rebounded in the eighteenth century thanks to the opening of trade with America and the beginning of the textile industry.
The city was still confined within its walls.
The only expansion was on the beach, in the neighborhood of La Barceloneta.
By the end of the period, the city had almost 100,000 inhabitants.
The period was not one of excessive urban reforms.
The sea wall was built in the first half of the 16th century.
The bastions of Llevant, Torre Nova, Sant Ramon and Migdia were placed on the sea wall.
The Plaça de la Seu was opened in the area around the cathedral in 1546.
The Plaça de San Iu was built with a space cut out of the Grand Royal Palace.
An artificial port was built in the 15th and 16th centuries to meet the needs of the important mercantile center that was Barcelona.
The old port at the foot of Montjuïc had been abandoned.
The city had only the beach to receive passengers and goods.
Deep-draught ships had to unload by means of boats and rope l
Streets were paved in the eighteenth century.
Sewers were installed in the eighteenth century.
Drinking water fountains were built in the eighteenth century.
Improvement works were carried out in the port in the eighteenth century.
The Principality of Catalonia and Barcelona itself saw much of its autonomy truncated in the eighteenth century with the victory of Philip V in the War of Succession.
The Nueva Planta Decree was issued in 1716.
The Nueva Planta Decree eliminated the Generalitat, the Corts and the Consell de Cent.
A military government replaced the Generalitat, the Corts and the Consell de Cent.
The municipal jurisdiction was reduced to the city in the eighteenth century.
The area of influence that the Consell de Cent had in the metropolitan area was lost in the eighteenth century.
There was a notable demographic increase in the eighteenth century.
The economy was progressively industrialized in the eighteenth century.
The Industrial Revolution occurred in the eighteenth century.
The arrival of the Bourbons generated a series of military engineering works.
The castle of Montjuïc was built in the eighteenth century.
The fortress of the Citadel was built in the eighteenth century.
1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood were demolished for the construction of the Citadel.
4500 people were left homeless and without compensation due to the demolition of 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood.
The Rec Comtal was diverted for the construction of the Citadel.
The Citadel was a pentagonal walled bastion with a protective moat and an esplanade of 120 m between the walls and the surrounding buildings.
Jorge Próspero de Verboom designed the Citadel.
The Citadel was demolished in the Revolution of 1868.
The park of the Citadel was installed on the perimeter of the Citadel.
Two new military roads were built in the eighteenth century
The Paseo Nuevo or Paseo de la Explanada was created in 1797. It was located next to the military Citadel.
The Paseo Nuevo was a wide avenue lined with poplars and elms. It was decorated with ornamental fountains.
The Paseo Nuevo was the main green space of the city for a period of time.
The Paseo Nuevo disappeared in the urbanization works of the park of the Citadel.
The Born and Boqueria markets were established in the eighteenth century.
The Born and Boqueria markets were the only two general supply markets.
In 1752, aspects such as weights and measures for the marketing of food products, in addition to coal, were regulated.
In the 19th century, there was a great economic revitalization in Barcelona.
The economic revitalization in Barcelona was linked primarily to the textile industry.
The textile industry revitalization led to a Catalan cultural renaissance.
Between 1854 and 1859, the city walls were demolished.
The demolition of the city walls allowed the city to expand.
The Eixample project was drawn up by Ildefons Cerdà in 1859.
After the revolution of 1868, the Citadel was demolished.
The land where the Citadel was located was transformed into a public park.
The population of Barcelona grew during the 19th century.
The population growth was due to immigration from the rest of Spain.
By the end of the 19th century, the population of Barcelona reached 400,000 inhabitants.
Chintz printing was well established in Barcelona since the 18th century.
The industrial era proper began with the founding in 1832 of the Bonaplata Factory.
The Bonaplata Factory was founded by Josep Bonaplata.
In 1849, the complex La España Industrial was opened in Sants.
The Cerdà Plan of 1859 established an area of occupation of 50% for plots.
New ordinances were drawn up in 1891 to take into account the new specificities of the Eixample plan and new links in the city.
The area of occupation of the plots was increased to 70% in the new ordinances of 1891.
Calle de Fernando (Ferran) was opened in 1827 between La Rambla and the Plaza de San Jaime (Sant Jaume).
The streets of Jaime I (Jaume I) and Princesa were built between 1849 and 1853, continuing Calle de Fernando towards the Borne.
The expansion of the Pla de Palau began in 1833, which was then the nerve center of the city.
The Royal Palace, the Llotja and the Aduana were present in the Pla de Palau.
The square was enlarged and the Portal de Mar was built between 1844 and 1848.
The Portal de Mar was a monumental gateway to Barceloneta from the old quarter, designed by Josep Massanès.
The city walls and the Portal de Mar were demolished in 1859.
Josep Massanès also proposed a widening plan in 1838 that was never completed.
The widening plan included the triangle between Canaletes, Plaça de la Universitat and Plaça Urquinaona.
The Plaça de Catalunya is located in the center of the triangle.
The confiscation of 1836 left numerous plots of land that were built on or converted into public spaces.
La Boqueria and Santa Catalina markets were created from the confiscated plots.
The Gran Teatro del Liceo (Liceu) was built on a confiscated plot.
Francesc Daniel Molina designed the Plaça Reial and the Plaça del Duc de Medinaceli.
New public squares were created from
The stations of Francia and Sants were created in 1854, and the station of Norte was created in 1862.
Barcelona became the center of a railway network in the shape of an 8, also known as the "Catalan eight".
The "Catalan eight" was formed by two rings that intersected in Barcelona.
In the 1880s, there were links with France, Madrid, Zaragoza, and Valencia.
There were also links with the rest of the Catalan provincial capitals.
Two companies operated at that time: Ferrocarril del Norte and MZA (Madrid-Zaragoza-Alicante).
These two companies were integrated in 1941 in RENFE.
In 1843, the Guardia Urbana de Barcelona was created.
The Guardia Urbana de Barcelona was in charge of the defense of public safety.
In 1938, the Guardia Urbana de Barcelona also assumed control of traffic and urban circulation.
In 1849, the Sociedad de Socorro Mutuo contra Incendios (Mutual Fire Aid Society) emerged.
In 1865, the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona (Barcelona 's Fire Extinguishing and Rescue Company) replaced the Sociedad de Socorro Mutuo contra Incendios.
The Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona was the first public fire department managed by the City Council.
The first chief of the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona was the architect Antoni Rovira i Trias.
The first firehouse of the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona was the Casa de Comunes Depósitos.
In 1908, animal-drawn vehicles were replaced by motor vehicles.
In 1913, the figure of the firefighter was professionalized.
In the middle of the century, the Diputation
In the early eighteenth century, the population of Barcelona was 34,000 inhabitants.
By the mid-nineteenth century, the population of Barcelona had grown to 160,000 inhabitants.
In the mid-nineteenth century, the population density in Barcelona was 850 inhabitants per hectare.
Pedro Felipe Monlau published the memoir "¡Abajo las murallas!" in 1841.
The memoir "¡Abajo las murallas!" called for the destruction of the walls surrounding Barcelona.
The walls surrounding Barcelona were not demolished until 1854.
In 1859, the City Council of Barcelona appointed a commission to promote a competition for urban expansion projects.
Antoni Rovira i Trias won the competition for urban expansion projects in Barcelona in 1859.
The Ministry of Development imposed the project of Ildefons Cerdà for the urban expansion of Barcelona.
Ildefons Cerdà is the author of a topographic plan of the Barcelona plain and a demographic and urbanistic study of the city (1855).
The Cerdà Plan (Plan de los alrededores de la ciudad de Barcelona y del proyecto para su mejora y ampliación, 1859) instituted an orthogonal layout between Montjuic and the Besòs.
The Cerdà Plan featured a system of straight northwest-southeast oriented streets, 20 meters wide.
The Cerdà Plan included other southwest-northeast oriented streets parallel to the coast and the Collserola mountain range.
Cerdà planned to build on only two sides of each block and leave the other spaces for gardens.
The buildings in the Eixample were designed with an octagonal floor plan characteristic of the Eixample.
The Cerdà Plan called for the construction of several main avenues: Diagonal, Meridiana, Paral·lel, Gran Via and Passeig de Sant Joan.
The Cerdà Plan included several large squares at the intersections of the main aven
The buildings in the Eixample of Barcelona were planned to have a height of 16 meters and a depth of 10 to 20 meters.
The Eixample was to be divided into sectors of 20 x 20 blocks, with each sector containing districts of 10 x 10 and neighborhoods of 5 x 5.
Each neighborhood in the Eixample was to have a church, a civic center, a school, a day care center, a nursing home, and other welfare centers.
Each district in the Eixample was to have a market and each sector a park.
The Eixample also had industrial and administrative facilities, and in the suburbs there was a slaughterhouse, a cemetery, and three hospitals.
Ildefons Cerdà, the designer of the Eixample, accompanied his project with several memoirs and statistical studies.
Cerdà's urbanistic theory was developed in three main points: hygienism, circulation, and multipurpose design.
Hygienism was based on Cerdà's Monografía estadística de la clase obrera, which criticized the living conditions within the walled city.
Circulation was intended to make public roads compatible between pedestrians and vehicular traffic.
The multipurpose design was intended to give a hygienic and functional city.
The Cerdà plot was superimposed on suburban layouts already existing or under development.
The naming of the new streets in the Eixample was entrusted to the writer Víctor Balaguer.
The new streets were named after territories linked to the Crown of Aragon, institutions, characters, battles, and historical events.
The Cerdà Plan was developed mainly outside the city walls.
The need for a project of "interior renovations" was raised to modernize the old core of the expanding city.
Miquel Garriga i Roca was the author of a joint plan of alignments (1862), the first exhaustive plan of the city.
Garriga's project foresaw the realignment of streets as the basic method of a broad renovation
Miquel Garriga i Roca was the author of a joint plan of alignments in 1862. This plan was the first exhaustive plan of the city, at 1/250 scale.
Garriga's project foresaw the realignment of streets as the basic method of a broad renovation of the city's interior.
The difficulty of executing Garriga's project and the absence of expropriation mechanisms led to the paralysis of this first project.
Àngel Baixeras carried out a more elaborate project in 1878.
Baixeras presented an expropriation bill to the Senate, which was approved in 1879.
Baixeras' project envisaged a thorough remodeling of the old city.
The most outstanding aspect of Baixeras' project was the opening of three major thoroughfares. These thoroughfares were initially called A, B and C.
The purpose of the three thoroughfares was to make the old city center more walkable.
Baixeras' project was not approved until 1895.
The execution of the project still had to wait until 1908.
Only the A road, renamed Vía Laietana, was built.
In 1860, an omnibus line had been opened along La Rambla.
The slowness of the carriages made this means of transport not very viable.
In 1872, rails were laid for the traction of the omnibus line.
This lightened the transport, with imperial model cars, pulled by two or four horses.
The line was extended from the port (Drassanes) to the village of Gracia.
Later, the line was extended from the Drassanes to La Barceloneta.
One of the first lines to operate was the English Barcelona Tramways Company Limited.
In 1899, the streetcars were electrified.
During these years, street furniture grew.
The increase of elements such as lampposts, fountains
The service was nationalized by the dictatorship of Primo de Rivera in 1925.
The Compañía Telefónica Nacional de España (National Telephone Company of Spain) was created in 1897.
In 1897, there were 2479 telephones in the city.
The number of telephones in the city grew progressively.
In 1917, there were about 10,000 telephones in the city.
In 1930, there were 26,000 telephones in the city.
In 1960, there were 200,000 telephones in the city.
In 1985, there were 750,000 telephones in the city.
In 2000, there were 850,000 telephones in the city.
Numerous supply markets were built in the last third of the century.
Many of these markets were made of iron.
The markets of Born, Sant Antoni, Hostafrancs, La Barceloneta, Concepción, Llibertat, Clot, Unió, Gràcia, and Sants were built in this way.
The Universal Exposition of 1888 was held in Barcelona.
The Universal Exposition of 1888 took place between April 8 and December 9, 1888.
The Universal Exposition of 1888 was held in the park of the Citadel.
The park of the Citadel was a land formerly belonging to the Army.
The Army's land was won for the city in 1868.
The Universal Exposition of 1888 had a great economic, social, urban, artistic and cultural impact on the city.
The remodeling project of the Citadel Park was commissioned to Josep Fontserè in 1872.
Josep Fontserè designed extensive gardens for the recreation of the citizens.
The gardens were part of the
The Golondrinas are pleasure boats that offered a promenade to visitors. They left in front of the statue of Columbus.

In 1891, Pere Garcia Fària proposed a project to regulate the city's sewage system. This project was called "Proyecto de saneamiento del subsuelo de Barcelona: alcantarillado, drenaje, residuos urbanos".
The sewage system proposed by Pere Garcia Fària placed special emphasis on hygienism. It established a visitable sewerage network that was 80 cm wide and 170 cm high.
The sewage system proposed by Pere Garcia Fària is maintained by a municipal brigade. This brigade still performs its functions.
The sewage system proposed by Pere Garcia Fària is a unitary system for rainwater and wastewater. It works mainly by gravity.
Large collectors are necessary in the lower part of the city because the sewage system proposed by Pere Garcia Fària works mainly by gravity.
The sewage network was extended from 31.2 km to 212 km thanks to the project proposed by Pere Garcia Fària.
The streets began to be urbanized with tiled sidewalks and cobblestone roadways during the nineteenth century.
The cobblestone roadways were replaced by asphalt in the 1960s.
The increase in population and new industrial needs led to an increase in water consumption during the nineteenth century.
A new pipeline was built from Dosrius (Maresme) at the end of the nineteenth century. This pipeline brought water to the city.
The new pipeline had a 17 km gallery and a 37 km aqueduct.
The Sociedad General de Aguas de Barcelona (AGBAR) was created in 1882. It was the main marketing company for water.
The Hospital Clínico y Provincial was created between 1895 and 1906. It was a new hospital that served the population of the new districts of the city.
The Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau was
The "Imperial Barcelona" or "Nova París del Migdia" was proposed by Prat de la Riba.
This proposal led to projects for improving infrastructures, railroads, transport, and equipment.
A free port was created to address the needs of an increasingly industrialized society.
Attention was given to education, culture, and green spaces to accommodate the growing population.
In 1897, Barcelona annexed six neighboring towns: Sants, Les Corts, San Gervasio de Cassolas, Gràcia, Sant Andreu de Palomar, and Sant Martí de Provençals.
In 1904, Sant Joan d'Horta was annexed; in 1921, Sarrià and Santa Creu d'Olorda; in 1924, Collblanc and the Marina de Hospitalet; and in 1943, Bon Pastor and Baró de Viver.
The annexations increased Barcelona's area from 15.5 km² to 77.8 km² and its population from 383,908 to 559,589.
The integration of the new municipalities required a plan to connect the city, which was put out to public tender in 1903.
Léon Jaussely, a French town planner, won the competition with his plan based on a structural scheme.
Jaussely's plan aimed to integrate the new municipalities with Barcelona and between them, focusing on organizational aspects over expansive ones.
The Jaussely Plan featured a road scheme of main axes, zoning of activities, and systematization of green spaces.
The plan envisaged large road infrastructures, parks, gardens, rail links, public and collective buildings, and facilities.
The Jaussely Plan was only partially realized and was reformulated in 1917 with the Romeu-Porcel Plan.
The most important action during this period was the opening of the Via Laietana in 1908.
The Via Laietana connected the Eixample with the sea
The new road was designed with the desire to create an avenue with a uniform appearance.
Most of the buildings on the new road are of noucentista appearance.
Some influence of the Chicago School is present in the buildings on the new road.
Criticism of the works for the opening of this road led to the paralysis of the construction of two other roads planned by Baixeras.
Antoni Darder made punctual interventions in the places of the two other roads in 1918.
Joaquim Vilaseca made punctual interventions in the places of the two other roads in 1932.
The projects of Antoni Darder and Joaquim Vilaseca were part of the Plan de Reforma, urbanización y enlace entre los puntos singulares del Casco Antiguo.
Soteras-Bordoy made punctual interventions in the places of the two other roads in 1956.
The projects of Soteras-Bordoy were part of the Plan parcial de Ordenación del Casco Antiguo de Barcelona.
Numerous demolitions of houses took place for the construction of the new road.
Some buildings of artistic value were moved during the demolitions.
The slopes of Tibidabo were urbanized in the early years of the century.
A wide avenue was built linking the avenue of San Gervasio with the mountain.
Single-family houses in the style of the English garden cities were built on the wide avenue.
A tramway was installed on the avenue.
A funicular was installed to ascend to the top of the mountain in 1901.
The Tibidabo Amusement Park was located at the top of the mountain.
The Vallvidrera funicular was opened in 1906.
An urbanization project was carried out on the Can Muntaner estate between 1900-1914.
The Can Muntaner estate is located at the foot of Mount Carmel, in the neighborhood of La Salut.
The Can
The service of the Tramways of Barcelona was suppressed in 1908 due to protests from the tramway companies.
In 1916, suburban lines appeared between Barcelona and Sant Just Desvern, Santa Coloma de Gramenet, Hospitalet, Badalona, El Prat, Sant Boi de Llobregat, Gavà and Sant Climent de Llobregat.
In 1922, city buses were reestablished and were operated by the Compañía General de Autobuses de Barcelona (General Bus Company of Barcelona, CGA).
The CGA was later absorbed by Tranvías de Barcelona, which went on to operate both transports.
The first 21 taxis were licensed in Barcelona in 1910.
By 1920, there were already a thousand taxis in Barcelona, with 64 stops throughout the city.
In 1928, the green light was incorporated as a "free" signal for taxis in Barcelona.
In 1931, the color black and yellow was established as the city's distinguishing color for taxis.
In the 1920s, urban transport in Barcelona was improved with the construction of the Barcelona Metro.
Work on the Barcelona Metro began in 1920 with the installation of two lines: line 3 (Lesseps-Liceo), and line 1 (Cataluña-Bordeta).
Line 3 of the Barcelona Metro was inaugurated in 1924, and line 1 was put into service in 1926.
The network of the Barcelona Metro was progressively expanded.
Today, Barcelona has 12 lines of the Barcelona Metro.
Initially, the Barcelona Metro was operated by three companies: Gran Metropolitano de Barcelona, Metropolitano Transversal and Ferrocarril de Sarrià a Barcelona.
The first two companies merged in 1957 into the company Ferrocarril Metropolitano de Barcelona.
The bus company Transportes de Barcelona was formed in 1979 together with the company Ferrocarril
The project of Rubió was not fully executed, but the city of Barcelona gained green land from 1910 to 1924, increasing from 72 ha to 450 ha.
The 1929 International Exposition was held in Montjuïc, Barcelona.
The Plaça d'Espanya, the avenue of Queen Maria Christina, and the mountain of Montjuïc were urbanized for the 1929 International Exposition.
Josep Puig i Cadafalch was one of the main architects of the 1929 International Exposition.
The 1929 International Exposition was a significant test bed for noucentisme, the successor style to modernisme.
The 1929 International Exposition took place from May 19, 1929, to January 15, 1930, covering an area of 116 ha and costing 180 million pesetas.

Jean-Claude Nicolas Forestier and Nicolau Maria Rubió i Tudurí created a Mediterranean and classicist garden ensemble on Montjuïc mountain for the 1929 International Exposition, including the Laribal, Miramar, and Greek Theater gardens.
The 1929 International Exposition had a significant impact on Barcelona's urban development, extending beyond Montjuïc to areas such as Tetuan, Urquinaona, Letamendi, and the Marina bridge.
Plaça de Catalunya was urbanized, Diagonal was extended to the west, Gran Vía to the southwest, and promenades of Gràcia and Sant Joan were improved around Gràcia.
Public works during this period included street asphalting and sewerage improvements, public toilet installations, and the replacement of gas lighting with electric lighting.

The city's communications were also enhanced with the construction of the Prat Airport, renovation of the France Station, improved suburban connections, elimination of level crossings, and the burying of train tracks in urban areas.
A funicular railway was built to reach Montjuïc mountain's top, with a second section to ascend to the castle
The Civil War led to a halt in the installation of traffic lights, which was reactivated in the 1950s.
The first synchronization of traffic lights took place in 1958, in Via Laietana.
In 1984, the Traffic Control Center was opened.
By 2004, the Traffic Control Center controlled 1,500 traffic light crossings.
The Second Republic and the grant of self-government to Catalonia favored the creation of various urban development projects in Barcelona.
By 1930, Barcelona had reached one million inhabitants and was deficient in infrastructure, housing, transport and facilities such as schools and hospitals.

In 1932, the autonomous government of Catalonia, the Generalitat, commissioned the brothers Nicolau and Santiago Rubió i Tudurí to develop a zoning project for the Catalan territory (Regional Planning).
The Regional Plan included a region of Barcelona, which included the plain of the city, the Baix Llobregat and the group of towns around the Tibidabo mountain.
The Regional Plan included considerations about the territory, both urban and natural, as well as in aspects such as agriculture and livestock, mining, industry, tourism, health and culture.
In 1936, the Territorial Division of Catalonia was carried out, based on a work commissioned by the Generalitat in 1932 to Pau Vila.
The Territorial Division of Catalonia sought a spatial organization based on administrative public services.
The Territorial Division of Catalonia resulted in a division into 9 regions and 38 comarques.
Barcelona became the capital of the Barcelonès comarca, which included Hospitalet de Llobregat, Badalona, Santa Coloma de Gramenet and Sant Adrià de Besòs.
In 1932, Catalonia had an area of 32 049 km², 2 920 748 inhabitants and 1070 municipalities.
In 1932-1935, the Macià Plan was
The Macià Plan proposed the creation of 400 x 400 m modules for the residential area. These modules are equivalent to nine blocks of the Eixample.
The residential modules would contain large housing complexes and social facilities.
The recreational area was conceived through green spaces located in these residential modules.
A large strip of land in the coastal area, between Barceloneta and Poblenou, would also have green spaces.
The Macià Plan proposed the creation of a vast complex for leisure called Ciutat de Repòs i Vacances. This complex would be located on the beaches of Viladecans, Gavà and Castelldefels.
The Macià Plan is considered one of the landmarks of Barcelona urban planning.
The Macià Plan was not put into practice.
The innovative and avant-garde design of the Macià Plan inspired the city's urban planning in the democratic period.
In the democratic period, there was a recovery of the seafront as a space intended for leisure.
An example of this recovery is the location of the Maremagnum shopping center on the Quai d'Espanya.
Another example is the creation of the Olympic Village and the various parks that follow one after the other from this to the Diagonal Mar area.
GATCPAC developed the Pla de Sanejament del Casc Antic (Old Town Sanitation Plan) between 1935-1937.
The Old Town Sanitation Plan provided for the demolition of blocks considered unhealthy.
The Old Town Sanitation Plan also provided for the sponging of urban space and the creation of hygienic facilities.
The Old Town Sanitation Plan was supported by a strong public intervention.
The Old Town Sanitation Plan favored the municipalization of urban property in 1937.
GATCPAC developed a workers' housing plan inspired by Le Corbusier's model of building à rédent.
The workers' housing plan was embodied in the Bloc house.
The Bloc house is an S-shaped housing complex of long, narrow
The growth of suburbs, such as Santa Coloma de Gramenet, Badalona, Sant Adrià de Besòs, Hospitalet de Llobregat, and Esplugues de Llobregat, led to an uninterrupted connection with Barcelona.
In 1942, the Municipal Ordinances were reformed, increasing the height of buildings in relation to street width.
In streets between 20 and 30 meters wide, buildings could reach up to 24.40 meters, equivalent to a first floor and six floors.
In streets over 30 meters wide, building heights could reach 27.45 meters, or seven floors.
This increase in buildability led to notable differences between buildings constructed at different times.
The increased buildability also resulted in numerous party walls that disfigured the urban space.
Pedro Bidagor was the head of urban planning of the new authorities after the war.
In 1945, Bidagor promoted the creation of the Barcelona Provincial Planning Commission.
The Barcelona Provincial Planning Commission was responsible for drawing up a planning project for Barcelona and its surroundings.
In 1953, the Regional Plan was developed by Josep Soteras.
The Regional Plan of 1953 aimed to integrate the city with neighboring municipalities to meet the strong demand for housing.
The Regional Plan of 1953 tried to curb real estate speculation and improve the urban environment.
The Land and Urban Planning Law of 1956 sought to bring rationality to urban development.
The Regional Plan of 1953 differentiated between zones of urban expansion, suburban or garden cities.
The Regional Plan of 1953 applied a polarized distribution of the territory.
In Barcelona, the Regional Plan of 1953 identified three zones as areas of growth: Levante, Poniente and Diagonal Norte.
The Regional Plan of 1953 reserved large areas for infrastructure, facilities and green spaces.
The Regional Plan of 1953 emphasized the enclosure of the Collserola mountain range as a large

The construction of three tunnels to cross the Collserola mountain range was proposed. Only the first tunnel, called the Vallvidrera tunnel, was built. The first phase of its construction was between 1969 and 1976, and the second phase was between 1982 and 1991.
The Rovira tunnel was built between 1983 and 1987. It links El Guinardó with El Carmel. It was supposed to link the Horta tunnel with the center of the city, but the Horta tunnel was never built.
Streetcars in Barcelona were replaced by buses. The metro network was expanded. In 1941, trolleybuses appeared, which disappeared in 1968.
The water supply in Barcelona was improved with the contribution coming from the Ter River. Natural gas was introduced. The electrical and telephone networks were renewed.
In 1952, Barcelona hosted the XXXV International Eucharistic Congress. A new neighborhood, known as Congreso (Congrés), was developed because of this event.

The Congreso neighborhood has a housing complex designed by Josep Soteras, Carles Marquès and Antoni Pineda. The complex is of 16.5 ha and includes a complex of 3,000 homes, 300 commercial premises, a church (parish of San Pío X), and various school, sports, and cultural services and facilities.
The open and closed blocks in the Congreso neighborhood alternate.
In the rest of the city, several renovations were carried out. The avenues of Príncipe de Asturias (now Riera de Cassoles) and Infanta Carlota (now Josep Tarradellas) were opened.
A monumental fountain was placed at the intersection of Gran Via de les Corts Catalanes and Passeig de Gràcia. The fountain is the work of Josep Soteras.
Calvo Sotelo square, now known as Francesc Macià, was landscaped. The project was by Nicolau Maria Rubió i Tudurí.
In 1957, the first section
Porcioles created the Municipal Housing Board.
The Municipal Housing Board developed large housing estates.
An example of a housing estate developed by the Municipal Housing Board is Montbau, which was built from 1958-1961.
Other examples of housing estates developed by the Municipal Housing Board include Southwest Besòs and Canyelles.
Some urban development actions of this period were positive, such as the covering of Aragón street.
The extension of the Gran Vía towards the Maresme is an example of a positive urban development action.
The adaptation of the seafront of Montjuic and the Barceloneta promenade are also examples of positive urban development actions.
However, the speculative rampage of large real estate operations generated popular discontent.
This popular discontent resulted in the so-called "urban social movements".
An example of an "urban social movement" was the opposition to the new layout of Lesseps square.
The reaction against the Partial Plan of Vallbona, Torre Baró and Trinitat was also an "urban social movement".
This reaction was organized by a neighborhood association called Nueve Barrios.
The new district of the city where the Partial Plan of Vallbona, Torre Baró and Trinitat is located is now known as Nueve Barrios.
Despite the rise of developmentalism, there were some attempts at urban reorganization.
The Master Plan for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona (1966) sought to make profitability and urban construction compatible.
However, the guiding character of the Master Plan for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona did not lead to practical realization.
The so-called Plan Barcelona 2000 (1970) established criteria for the future city.
The importance given to infrastructure predominates in Plan Barcelona 2000.
A realistic commitment was made to the disorderly nature of urban growth in Plan Barcelona 2000.
In 1970, a project for a Universal Exposition in 1982 emerged.
The project for the
The work of the architect included the Mirador del Alcalde and Joan Maragall gardens on Montjuic, located around the Albéniz Palacete.
He also worked on the Putget, Guineueta and Villa Amelia parks in Barcelona.
The end of the dictatorship and the advent of democracy brought a new era in the architectural and urban planning panorama of the city.
The new socialist councils of Narcís Serra (1979-1982) and Pasqual Maragall (1982-1997) were committed to urban planning and architecture as the city's hallmarks.
The new consistory appointed Oriol Bohigas as Urban Planning delegate.
A period of strong public investment in the city began, leading to a radical change in the urban physiognomy and a new projection of Barcelona at international level.
Municipal actions in those years focused on reconstruction versus expansion.
The concept of the city as a sum of realities was prioritized, opposing the vision of the city as a unitary entity.
Attention was given to local needs, aiming to palliate both quantitative and qualitative deficits.
Each intervention in public space served as an engine of urban regeneration, compensating the peripheries with a "monumentalization" of their environment.

Industrial restructuring, promoted by the Plan for the reindustrialization of the center of Barcelona, resulted in the creation of an Zona d'Urgent Reindustrialització (Urgent Reindustrialization Zone) (ZUR).
The new industrial development was based on factors such as R&D, and on the commitment to new technologies.
The General Metropolitan Urban Development Plan (1976) was drafted by Joan Antoni Solans.
The plan aimed to curb speculation and rehabilitate the most degraded urban spaces.
Special emphasis was placed on social, welfare and cultural facilities.
The Metropolitan Corporation of Barcelona was created, which included the capital and 26 surrounding municipalities.
Three general lines of action were outlined: small-scale urban rehabilitation, urban restructuring
The aim was to decongest the center of Barcelona by promoting various sectors of the urban periphery.

Twelve areas were delimited for this purpose. These areas were: RENFE-Meridiana, Diagonal-Sarrià, Tarragona street, Cerdà square, Port Vell, Glòries square, Diagonal-Prim (future Fòrum area), Sant Andreu-Sagrera and four areas related to the Olympic Games: Montjuic, Diagonal-Zona Universitària, Vall d'Hebron and Carles I-Avinguda Icària (future Olympic Village).
During this period, numerous stretches of the city's roads were improved.
Wide and often landscaped avenues were designed mainly for pedestrian traffic.

Some examples of these avenues are: Avinguda de Gaudí, Avinguda de Josep Tarradellas, Carrer Tarragona, the connection between the old Rambles and the Rambla de Catalunya, Passeig de Lluís Companys, Avinguda de la Reina Maria Cristina, Via Júlia and Rambla de Prim.
Numerous squares were also opened and refurbished.
Many of these squares were also landscaped.
Some examples of these squares are: Salvador Allende, Baixa de Sant Pere, Sant Agustí Vell, la Mercè, Sóller and Robacols.
Among the sectoral plans developed during these years, those of Ciutat Vella, Carmel, Gràcia, Sarrià, Sant Andreu and Poblenou are worth mentioning.
During these years, policies to promote affordable housing were also carried out.
In Eixample, the recovery of the block courtyards as green areas or public services was sought.
In 1988, the Pla Especial de Clavegueram de Barcelona (Special Sewerage Plan of Barcelona) (PECB) was approved.
This plan remodeled the network of coastal sewers.
The plan eliminated practically half of the city's flood areas.
The plan also promoted the
The coastal railroad had to be buried for the Olympic Village.
Sewage treatment plants had to be built for the Olympic Village.
Wastewater that had previously gone directly into the sea had to be channeled for the Olympic Village.
A new port, named Olympic Port, was built for the Olympic Village.
New beaches were established and regenerated for the Olympic Village.
New road and transport axes were laid out, such as Avinguda d'Icària, for the Olympic Village.
The Telephone Exchange was installed in the area of the Olympic Village from 1989-1992.
The Meteorology Center was installed in the area of the Olympic Village from 1990-1992.
The construction of two large skyscrapers, Hotel Arts and Torre Mapfre, changed the physiognomy of Barcelona.
The Vall d'Hebron neighborhood was planned according to a project by Eduard Bru from 1989-1991.
The Olympic Press Village was located in the Vall d'Hebron neighborhood and was designed by Carlos Ferrater.

New parks and gardens were created for the Olympic Games, such as the parks of Mirador del Migdia, Poblenou, Carles I and three designed by the firm Martorell-Bohigas-Mackay: the park of the Cascades, the Olympic Port and the park of Nova Icària.
The Old port (Port Vell) was remodeled with a project by Jordi Henrich and Olga Tarrasó for the Olympic Games.
The Maremagnum leisure center was created in the Old port (Port Vell) for the Olympic Games.
The Rambla de Mar, a pivoting bridge designed by Helio Piñón and Albert Viaplana, connects the Maremagnum leisure center to land.
A Coastal Plan was instituted with a view to the regeneration of the city's beaches for the Olympic Games.
The city's beaches were cleaned and filled with sand from the seabed for the Olympic Games.

The general planning of Barcelona was carried out between 1989 and 1992 by Josep Acebillo, who was the technical director of the Municipal Institute for Urban Development, and Alfred Morales, who was the coordinator of transport and circulation of the Barcelona City Council.
There are currently three ring roads in Barcelona.
The first two ring roads, the Ronda de Dalt and the Ronda del Mig, circumvent Barcelona.
The Ronda del Mig, also known as the "middle" ring road, crosses the city and receives different names depending on the section.
The Ronda del Mig is named Passeig de la Zona Franca, Carrer de Badal, Rambla del Brasil, Gran Via de Carles III, Ronda del General Mitre, Travesera de Dalt, and Ronda del Guinardó.
A campaign to restore facades and monuments and to adapt dividing walls was carried out in Barcelona from 1986 to 1992.
The campaign was called Barcelona posa't guapa (Barcelona make yourself pretty).
Josep Emili Hernández-Cros, from the Heritage area of the City Council, directed the campaign.
The celebration of the 1992 Olympic Games was a challenge for the urban planning of Barcelona.
The urban planning of the city was a platform for a determined strategic urban planning action during the Games.
There was a perfect harmony between social and economic agents during the Games.
The Games led to a new projection of the city both nationally and internationally.
The "Barcelona model" was talked about as an integrative project of urban reform that was exportable to other cities.
The last years of the 20th century were marked by the search for a more sustainable urban planning based on ecological criteria.
Public spaces adapted to the environment and designed for the residents were sought during the last years of the 20th century.
Community facilities and services were emphasized during the last years of the 20th century.
The Sustainable Barcelona Civic Forum was held in 1998 to define the criteria for a more sustainable urban planning
The preservation of the productive business fabric of the area was promoted, focusing on companies dedicated to new technologies.
The area of action is 115 hectares.
The 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures was celebrated in the city.
The Besòs area was recovered and the Poblenou neighborhood was regenerated.
The new Diagonal Mar neighborhood was built.
The city was provided with new parks and spaces for the leisure of the citizens.
The site was designed by Elías Torres and José Antonio Martínez Lapeña.
A 16-hectare multipurpose esplanade was built.
A large photovoltaic panel was installed at one end of the esplanade.
The photovoltaic panel became one of the emblems of the event.
The polynuclear grid structure was reinforced in the urban planning of the new millennium.
New urban centers such as the Fòrum, 22@ and La Sagrera emerged.
The Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes is being remodeled.
The undergrounding of automobile traffic is planned in Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes.
The recovery of the land for public use is planned in Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes.
The arrival of the high-speed train improved communications in the city.
The high-speed train links the Catalan capital with Madrid and Paris.
The Mediterranean Corridor is in the project.
The port and El Prat airport have been expanded.
The aim of the expansion is to make Barcelona the logistics hub of southern Europe.
The metro network has been expanded.
Several lines (3 and 5) were extended.
Some new lines (9, 10 and 11) were created.
Some metro lines are fully automated.
An orthogonal rearrangement of the bus network was initiated in 2012.
The aim of the rearrangement is to create a bus

The PDU, or Plan de Urbanisme de l'Àrea Metropolitana de Barcelona, is meant to complement the 1976 General Metropolitan Plan. Its aim is to promote the urban and social transformation of the metropolitan area of the Catalan capital.
The metropolitan area of the Catalan capital is made up of 36 municipalities and 3.5 million inhabitants.

The PDU has two conceptual objectives. The first objective is to define a metropolitan urban planning model that integrates the current diversity, is ecologically sustainable, economically efficient and socially cohesive. The second objective is to establish the methods and tools necessary to carry out this model.
In September 2016, a pilot test was initiated for the adaptation of certain sets of city blocks as "superblocks".
Superblocks are intermediate spaces between the block and the neighborhood, with restricted vehicle traffic to enhance pedestrian traffic, bicycle circulation and public transport.
The first pilot test was carried out on a set of nine blocks in Poblenou.
Vertical and horizontal signs were changed to mark the superblock area.
Traffic is prohibited in a straight line, so that vehicles can only turn at intersections, and is limited to 10 km/h.
The interior space between blocks is used for public spaces.
An ideas competition has been organized among architecture students for the design of the public spaces.
In 2020, a new phase of creating superblocks in the Eixample district began.
The aim is to establish 42 new green axes and squares within ten years, until 2030.
The first axis of action is Consell de Cent street.
The creation of four new agoras in Rocafort, Borrell, Enric Granados and Girona is planned.
One out of every three streets in the Eixample would give priority to pedestrianization and public and sustainable transport.
Changes are done by axes instead of blocks, with the subsequent creation of new plazas on intersecting axes.
Private traffic is restricted to residents, with a maximum speed of 10 km/h.
